user.description: Found {legacy_count} Adaptive Cover configuration(s) that can be imported

data.manual_ignore_intermediate: Ignore intermediate positions during manual override (opening and closing)
data.return_sunset: Always adjust position to sunset default at end time; Useful if end time is before actual sunset

data_description.delta_position: Minimum position change (%) required before adjusting the cover. Prevents tiny adjustments as sun moves slowly. Typical values: 1-2% (very responsive, may adjust frequently), 5% (balanced, recommended for most), 10% (less frequent, larger movements). Example: If cover is at 30% and sun moves slightly, only adjust if new position is 35% or more (with 5% threshold). Reduces motor wear and noise from constant tiny adjustments.
data_description.delta_time: Minimum time (minutes) between cover adjustments. Prevents rapid position changes. Typical values: 2-3 min (very responsive, may be noisy), 5-10 min (balanced, recommended), 15-20 min (slow, gentle adjustments). If sun changes rapidly (clouds, shadows), integration waits this long before adjusting again. Reduces motor wear and provides smoother operation. Minimum is 2 minutes.
data_description.start_time: Don't start automatic control before this time (24-hour format). Use this to sleep in without morning blinds (set to 08:00 or later), match your routine (set to when you wake up), or leave blank to start at sunrise. Example: '07:30' means automatic control begins at 7:30 AM. Manual control still works before this time.
data_description.start_entity: Entity representing starting time state, overriding the fixed start time set above. Useful for automating the start time with an entity (e.g., sensor that provides wake-up time based on calendar or sleep tracking).
data_description.manual_override_duration: How long (minutes) to pause automatic control after manual adjustment. When you manually move the cover, automatic control pauses. Typical values: 10-15 min (short pause, resume tracking soon), 30 min (medium pause, balanced), 60-120 min (long pause, keep manual position longer), 0 (disabled, immediately resume automatic control - not recommended). Gives you control when you want it, resumes automation later.
data_description.manual_override_reset: Reset the manual override timer after each manual adjustment. If enabled, each manual change restarts the override duration. If disabled, the duration only applies to the first manual adjustment (subsequent changes don't extend the pause). Enable this if you want the override period to 'renew' with each manual touch.
data_description.end_time: Stop automatic control after this time (24-hour format). Use this to keep evening privacy (set to 18:00 or 19:00), return to default before bed, or leave blank to continue until sunset. Example: '20:00' means automatic control stops at 8:00 PM. Manual control still works after this time.
data_description.end_entity: Entity representing ending time state, overriding the fixed end time set above. Useful for automating the end time with an entity (e.g., sensor that provides bedtime based on calendar or daily routine).
data_description.manual_threshold: Position difference (%) that counts as 'manual override' (default: 1%). If you manually move cover by this amount, override detection triggers. Typical values: 1-2% (sensitive, detects small adjustments), 5% (less sensitive, recommended), 10% (only large manual changes count). Prevents accidental override detection from small motor drifts or position reporting variations.
data_description.manual_ignore_intermediate: Ignore intermediate positions during manual opening and closing operations. Enable this to prevent override detection from transitional positions while the cover is moving to your target position. Useful if your cover reports many intermediate values during movement.
data_description.return_sunset: Always adjust position to sunset default at end time, even if it's before actual sunset. Enable this to ensure the cover moves to sunset position when the end time is reached, rather than waiting for astronomical sunset. Useful if your end time is before sunset and you want consistent evening positioning.
data_description.open_close_threshold: Position threshold for covers that only support open/close commands (not position control). When the calculated position is greater than or equal to this threshold, the cover opens; when below, it closes. Default: 50% (opens at midpoint or above). Higher values (60-70%) keep cover closed more often, lower values (30-40%) open more often. Only affects covers without position support - covers with position control ignore this setting and use exact calculated positions.
data_description.enable_diagnostics: Enable additional diagnostic sensor entities for debugging and monitoring. When enabled, creates extra entities that show: solar position (azimuth/elevation), last cover action details, control method status, and calculation diagnostics. Default: Disabled (to avoid entity clutter). Enable this if you want detailed visibility into the integration's decision-making process or need to troubleshoot behavior. Diagnostic entities are disabled by default in the UI.

data.inverse_state: Inverse the state (needed for some covers that don't follow HA guidelines)
data.interp: Set custom open/close positions for My Cover, if it doesn't fully operate at 0-100%

data_description.set_azimuth: Direction your window faces (0-359°). North=0°, East=90°, South=180°, West=270°. Example: A south-facing window = 180°. Use a compass app or check sun at noon to determine. This tells the integration where your window points so it can calculate sun angles accurately.
data_description.window_height: Height of your window in meters (from bottom to top of the glass area). Examples: Standard door = 2.0m, Small window = 1.5m, Floor-to-ceiling = 2.5m. Measure from where the cover starts to where it ends when fully extended. Used to calculate optimal cover position to block direct sunlight. Note: 1 meter ≈ 3.3 feet.
data_description.distance_shaded_area: How far you want to ALLOW direct sunlight to reach into the room (in meters). This defines your acceptable 'glare zone' - the area where sunlight can reach the floor. The cover position adjusts to maintain this boundary as the sun moves across the sky. Common configurations: Small glare zone (0.3-0.5m) keeps sunlight very close to the window (use when you want maximum shade); Medium glare zone (0.5-1.0m) allows sun to reach desk or seating area (balanced, most common for living spaces); Large glare zone (2.0-3.0m) allows sunlight deep into the room (good for dark rooms or passive solar heating). KEY CONCEPT: LARGER value = MORE sunlight allowed farther into room = cover stays HIGHER/MORE OPEN; SMALLER value = LESS sunlight into room = cover drops LOWER/MORE CLOSED. Measure from the inside of your window to where you want the sun boundary to be.
data_description.default_percentage: Cover position when sun is not in front of window (0-100%). 0% = Fully closed/lowered (maximum privacy/shade), 50% = Half open (balanced light and privacy), 100% = Fully open/raised (maximum light). This is the 'rest position' used when sun tracking is not active (sun is behind the window, blocked by obstacles, or outside tracking hours).
data_description.max_position: Maximum cover position limit (0-100%). Cover will never go above this value. Use this to: prevent cover from fully opening (set to 80%), keep some shade at all times (set to 60-70%), protect from jamming at top (set to 95%). This creates an upper boundary for all automatic positions.
data_description.fov_left: How wide the sun tracking area is on the LEFT side of the window (in degrees). Standard windows: 45° (90° total coverage with both sides), Wide windows or glass doors: 60-75°, Narrow windows: 30°. Think of this as peripheral vision - how far to the left should we track the sun? Combined with fov_right, this defines the horizontal tracking zone.
data_description.fov_right: How wide the sun tracking area is on the RIGHT side of the window (in degrees). Standard windows: 45° (90° total coverage with both sides), Wide windows or glass doors: 60-75°, Narrow windows: 30°. Think of this as peripheral vision - how far to the right should we track the sun? Combined with fov_left, this defines the horizontal tracking zone.
data_description.group: Select the cover entities to control via this integration instance. You can select multiple covers to control them as a group (all will receive the same position commands). Only select covers that serve this particular window - create separate integration instances for different windows.
data_description.inverse_state: Enable for covers where position logic is reversed. Standard: 0 = closed/lowered, 100 = open/raised. Inverted: 0 = open/raised, 100 = closed/lowered. Check this ONLY if your cover shows opposite behavior, 100% closes instead of opens, or documentation says 'inverted' or 'reversed'. Test your cover manually first to confirm. Most covers don't need this.
data_description.sunset_position: Cover position to set after sunset (0-100%). Common uses: Privacy (0% = fully closed), Open for night air (100%), Partial privacy (30-50%). This overrides the default position after sun sets. Leave blank to keep using default position (no special sunset behavior).
data_description.sunset_offset: Minutes to shift sunset time (± adjustment). Positive value: Apply sunset position X minutes AFTER sunset. Negative value: Apply sunset position X minutes BEFORE sunset. Zero: Exactly at sunset. Use positive value (e.g., 30) if you want covers to stay open a bit past sunset. Use negative value (e.g., -30) to close early while sun is still low.
data_description.sunrise_offset: Minutes to shift sunrise time (± adjustment). Positive value: Start automatic control X minutes AFTER sunrise. Negative value: Start automatic control X minutes BEFORE sunrise. Zero: Exactly at sunrise. Use positive value (e.g., 60) if you want to sleep in past sunrise. Combines with Start Time setting (uses whichever is later).
data_description.climate_mode: Enable advanced climate-aware control based on temperature and weather. When enabled, cover behavior changes by season: WINTER (cold) opens fully on sunny days to gain solar heat; SUMMER (hot) closes fully to prevent overheating; INTERMEDIATE uses normal sun tracking. Requires: Temperature sensor (indoor or outdoor). Optional: Presence sensor, weather integration, lux sensor. Recommended for energy efficiency and comfort.
data_description.blind_spot: Enable if you have obstacles blocking sun in part of the tracking area (trees, nearby buildings, roof overhang, balcony). When enabled, you define an azimuth + elevation range where sun is blocked. Cover ignores sun position when it's in this 'blind spot'. Leave disabled if you have clear view to sun all day.
data_description.min_elevation: Track sun only when elevation is ABOVE this angle (degrees above horizon). Sun elevation: 0°=horizon, 45°=halfway to zenith, 90°=directly overhead. Use this to ignore sun at certain times. Example: Set to 15° to ignore low morning/evening sun. Leave empty to track sun at all elevations.
data_description.max_elevation: Track sun only when elevation is BELOW this angle (degrees above horizon). Sun elevation: 0°=horizon, 45°=halfway to zenith, 90°=directly overhead. Use this to ignore sun at certain times. Example: Set to 60° to ignore high midday sun. Leave empty to track sun at all elevations.
data_description.interp: Enable custom position mapping (advanced users only). Maps calculated positions to different actual positions using a curve. Use cases: cover doesn't move linearly, prefer certain ranges (more closed or more open), calibrate for unusual cover behavior. Leave disabled for normal operation. Lists must have equal length.

vertical.description: Configure your vertical blind or shade. Adjust window orientation, size, and tracking behavior.
vertical.title: Vertical cover

data_description.temp_entity: Temperature sensor for climate mode (indoor or outdoor). Used to determine winter/summer strategies. Indoor sensor recommended (measures room comfort). Outdoor sensor alternative (tracks outside weather). Thermostat: Can use current_temperature attribute. Make sure sensor units match your Home Assistant unit system (°C or °F).
data_description.presence_entity: Optional presence sensor (home/away detection). Supported types: device_tracker, person, zone, binary_sensor. When AWAY: Summer closes fully (save on AC), Winter opens on sunny days (passive solar heating). When HOME: Use normal climate strategies with weather awareness. Leave empty to always assume someone is home. Saves energy when away, maintains comfort when home.
data_description.weather_entity: Optional weather integration for cloud-aware control. When weather = cloudy/rainy: Skips winter solar gain (no sun to capture), Returns to default position (no overheating risk). When weather = sunny/clear: Applies full climate strategies. Leave empty to assume always sunny (simpler). Recommended if you have weather integration - avoids unnecessary closes.
data_description.outside_temp: Optional outdoor temperature sensor for better summer detection. When set, summer mode requires BOTH: Indoor temperature > high threshold AND Outdoor temperature > outside threshold. Prevents closing covers when it's cool outside (open for breeze). Leave empty to use only indoor temperature. Recommended if you have outdoor sensor - improves comfort.
data_description.temp_low: Temperature threshold for WINTER mode (in your system units). When temperature < this value: Cover opens fully on sunny days to gain heat. Recommended values: °C: 18-20°C (65-68°F), °F: 65-68°F. Adjust based on your comfort preference. Lower value = winter mode less often (only when very cold). Higher value = winter mode more often (prioritize solar gain).
data_description.temp_high: Temperature threshold for SUMMER mode (in your system units). When temperature > this value: Cover closes fully to prevent overheating. Recommended values: °C: 23-25°C (73-77°F), °F: 73-77°F. Adjust based on your cooling preference. Lower value = summer mode sooner (aggressive cooling). Higher value = summer mode later (tolerate more heat).
data_description.transparent_blind: Check this if your blind is see-through (sheer/light fabric). Changes summer behavior: Transparent ON closes to 0% in summer (block heat, keep light). Transparent OFF uses calculated position. Transparent blinds reduce heat but allow light through. Leave unchecked for opaque/blackout blinds.
data_description.lux_entity: Optional light intensity sensor for precise sun detection (indoor or outdoor). Measures visible light in lux units. Set threshold value for 'sunny' condition. Typical: 5000-10000 lux for direct sun. When below threshold: Treat as cloudy, skip climate strategies. Leave empty if you don't have this sensor. Advanced feature - most users don't need this.
data_description.lux_threshold: Lux level threshold (when to consider 'sunny'). When sensor reads above this value: Sun is present, apply climate strategies. When below: Treat as cloudy, use default position. Typical values: 5000-10000 lux for direct sunlight, 2000-3000 lux for bright indirect light. Adjust based on sensor placement and sensitivity.
data_description.irradiance_entity: Optional solar radiation sensor for precise sun detection (outdoor). Measures solar power in W/m² units. Set threshold value for 'sunny' condition. Typical: 300-500 W/m² for direct sun. When below threshold: Treat as cloudy, skip climate strategies. Leave empty if you don't have this sensor. Advanced feature - most users don't need this.
data_description.irradiance_threshold: Irradiance level threshold (when to consider 'sunny'). When sensor reads above this value (W/m²): Sun is present, apply climate strategies. When below: Treat as cloudy, use default position. Typical values: 300-500 W/m² for direct sunlight, 100-200 W/m² for cloudy day. Adjust based on your climate and preference.

climate.description: Configure climate-aware control for energy efficiency and comfort. These settings enable the integration to adapt cover behavior based on temperature, weather, and presence.
climate.title: Climate settings

data_description.weather_state: Select weather states that mean 'sun is out' for climate mode. Recommended selection (pre-filled): ☑ sunny (direct sun), ☑ partlycloudy (some sun), ☐ cloudy (no direct sun), ☐ clear (usually night). When current weather matches selection: Apply climate strategies. When no match: Use default position (no sun assumed). Most users should keep the defaults.

data.inverse_state: Inverse the state (needed for some covers that don't follow HA guidelines)
data.interp: Set custom open/close positions for My Cover, if it doesn't fully operate at 0-100%

data_description.set_azimuth: Direction your window/door faces (0-359°). North=0°, East=90°, South=180°, West=270°. Example: A south-facing patio door = 180°. Use a compass app or check sun at noon to determine. This tells the integration where your awning points so it can calculate sun angles accurately.
data_description.window_height: Height of the awning mounting point from the ground or work area level (in meters). This is the vertical distance from the floor/patio to where the awning is attached to the wall. Examples: Standard door height = 2.0-2.5m, Upper window = 3.0m. Used to calculate sun angle and shadow projection.
data_description.length_awning: Maximum extension length of your awning in meters (fully extended). Measure from mounting point to the end of the fabric when fully out. Examples: Standard patio awning = 2.0-3.0m, Small window awning = 1.0-1.5m, Large commercial = 4.0m+. Used to calculate how far the awning needs to extend to block sun.
data_description.angle: Angle of the awning when extended (0-45°). 0° = Horizontal/flat (maximum coverage), 15° = Slight slope (typical for drainage), 30° = Steep slope (strong sun angle), 45° = Very steep (rarely used). Check your awning manufacturer specs. Most awnings are 0-15°. Affects shadow calculation for proper sun blocking.
data_description.distance_shaded_area: How far you want to ALLOW direct sunlight to reach into the covered area (in meters). This defines your acceptable 'glare zone' from the building wall outward. The awning extension adjusts to maintain this boundary as the sun moves. Common: Patio seating (1.5-2.0m), Doorway only (0.5-1.0m), Full patio (2.5-3.5m). KEY CONCEPT: LARGER value = MORE sunlight allowed farther from wall = awning EXTENDS MORE; SMALLER value = LESS sunlight into area = awning RETRACTS MORE. Measure from the wall to where you want the sun boundary to be.
data_description.default_percentage: Awning position when sun is not in front (0-100%). 0% = Fully retracted (protected, stored), 50% = Half extended, 100% = Fully extended (maximum coverage). This is the 'rest position' used when sun tracking is not active. Most users set to 0% to protect awning when not needed.
data_description.max_position: Maximum awning extension limit (0-100%). Awning will never extend beyond this value. Use this to: prevent full extension (set to 80%), keep some retraction for wind safety (set to 70%), protect from over-extension (set to 95%). This creates an upper boundary for all automatic positions.
data_description.fov_left: How wide the sun tracking area is on the LEFT side (in degrees). Standard patios: 45° (90° total coverage with both sides), Wide patios: 60-75°, Narrow doors: 30°. Think of this as peripheral vision - how far to the left should we track the sun? Combined with fov_right, this defines the horizontal tracking zone.
data_description.fov_right: How wide the sun tracking area is on the RIGHT side (in degrees). Standard patios: 45° (90° total coverage with both sides), Wide patios: 60-75°, Narrow doors: 30°. Think of this as peripheral vision - how far to the right should we track the sun? Combined with fov_left, this defines the horizontal tracking zone.
data_description.group: Select the cover entities to control via this integration instance. You can select multiple awnings to control them as a group (all will receive the same position commands). Only select awnings that serve this particular area - create separate integration instances for different locations.
data_description.inverse_state: Enable for awnings where position logic is reversed. Standard: 0 = retracted, 100 = extended. Inverted: 0 = extended, 100 = retracted. Check this ONLY if your awning shows opposite behavior, 100% retracts instead of extends, or documentation says 'inverted' or 'reversed'. Test your awning manually first to confirm. Most awnings don't need this.
data_description.sunset_position: Awning position to set after sunset (0-100%). Common uses: Retract for protection (0% = fully retracted, recommended), Partial extension for evening use (30-50%), Keep extended (100%). This overrides the default position after sun sets. Leave blank to keep using default position (no special sunset behavior).
data_description.sunset_offset: Minutes to shift sunset time (± adjustment). Positive value: Apply sunset position X minutes AFTER sunset. Negative value: Apply sunset position X minutes BEFORE sunset. Zero: Exactly at sunset. Use positive value (e.g., 30) if you want awning to stay extended a bit past sunset. Use negative value (e.g., -30) to retract early for safety.
data_description.sunrise_offset: Minutes to shift sunrise time (± adjustment). Positive value: Start automatic control X minutes AFTER sunrise. Negative value: Start automatic control X minutes BEFORE sunrise. Zero: Exactly at sunrise. Use positive value (e.g., 60) if you want delayed morning extension. Combines with Start Time setting (uses whichever is later).
data_description.climate_mode: Enable advanced climate-aware control based on temperature and weather. When enabled, awning behavior changes by season: WINTER (cold) retracts on sunny days to allow solar heat gain into building; SUMMER (hot) extends fully to prevent overheating; INTERMEDIATE uses normal sun tracking. Requires: Temperature sensor. Optional: Presence, weather, lux sensors. Recommended for energy efficiency.
data_description.blind_spot: Enable if you have obstacles blocking sun in part of the tracking area (trees, nearby buildings, roof overhang, pergola). When enabled, you define an azimuth + elevation range where sun is blocked. Awning ignores sun position when it's in this 'blind spot'. Leave disabled if you have clear view to sun all day.
data_description.min_elevation: Track sun only when elevation is ABOVE this angle (degrees above horizon). Sun elevation: 0°=horizon, 45°=halfway to zenith, 90°=directly overhead. Use this to ignore sun at certain times. Example: Set to 20° to ignore very low sun that clears the awning. Leave empty to track sun at all elevations.
data_description.max_elevation: Track sun only when elevation is BELOW this angle (degrees above horizon). Sun elevation: 0°=horizon, 45°=halfway to zenith, 90°=directly overhead. Use this to ignore sun at certain times. Example: Set to 70° to ignore high sun that doesn't reach under cover. Leave empty to track sun at all elevations.
data_description.interp: Enable custom position mapping (advanced users only). Maps calculated positions to different actual positions using a curve. Use cases: awning doesn't move linearly, prefer certain ranges (more retracted or more extended), calibrate for unusual awning behavior. Leave disabled for normal operation. Lists must have equal length.

horizontal.description: Configure your horizontal awning or canopy. Adjust orientation, dimensions, and extension behavior for optimal sun protection.
horizontal.title: Horizontal cover

data.inverse_state: Inverse the state (needed for some covers that don't follow HA guidelines)
data.interp: Set custom open/close positions for My Cover, if it doesn't fully operate at 0-100%

data_description.set_azimuth: Direction your window faces (0-359°). North=0°, East=90°, South=180°, West=270°. Example: An east-facing window = 90°. Use a compass app or check sun position to determine. This tells the integration where your window points so it can calculate the optimal slat angle to block direct sunlight.
data_description.slat_depth: Width of each slat in meters (measure one slat front to back). Common sizes: Mini blinds (1 inch) = 0.025m, Standard blinds (2 inch) = 0.05m, Wide slats (2.5-3 inch) = 0.065-0.075m. Measure a single slat with a ruler. More precise measurement = better sun blocking calculation. Note: Enter in METERS not centimeters.
data_description.slat_distance: Vertical spacing between slat centers in meters. Measure from the middle of one slat to the middle of the next slat (vertically). Usually slightly more than slat depth to allow overlap when closed. Common: 0.03-0.08m depending on blind type. Used to calculate the tilt angle that blocks all direct sunlight while maximizing view and light. Note: Enter in METERS not centimeters.
data_description.default_percentage: Slat tilt position when sun is not in front of window (0-100%). 0% = Closed horizontal (privacy, darkness), 50% = Partially open (balanced), 100% = Fully open (maximum light). This is the 'rest position' used when sun tracking is not active (sun is behind the window, blocked by obstacles, or outside tracking hours).
data_description.max_position: Maximum slat tilt limit (0-100%). Slats will never open beyond this value. Use this to: keep some privacy at all times (set to 70-80%), never fully open (set to 90%), prevent maximum tilt (set to 95%). This creates an upper boundary for all automatic tilt angles.
data_description.fov_left: How wide the sun tracking area is on the LEFT side of the window (in degrees). Standard windows: 45° (90° total coverage with both sides), Wide windows: 60-75°, Narrow windows: 30°. Think of this as peripheral vision - how far to the left should we track the sun? Combined with fov_right, this defines the horizontal tracking zone.
data_description.fov_right: How wide the sun tracking area is on the RIGHT side of the window (in degrees). Standard windows: 45° (90° total coverage with both sides), Wide windows: 60-75°, Narrow windows: 30°. Think of this as peripheral vision - how far to the right should we track the sun? Combined with fov_left, this defines the horizontal tracking zone.
data_description.group: Select the cover entities to control via this integration instance. You can select multiple venetian blinds to control them as a group (all will receive the same tilt commands). Only select blinds that serve this particular window - create separate integration instances for different windows.
data_description.inverse_state: Enable for blinds where tilt logic is reversed. Standard: 0 = closed/horizontal, 100 = open/vertical. Inverted: 0 = open/vertical, 100 = closed/horizontal. Check this ONLY if your blind shows opposite behavior, 100% closes instead of opens, or documentation says 'inverted' or 'reversed'. Test your blind manually first to confirm. Most blinds don't need this.
data_description.sunset_position: Slat tilt position to set after sunset (0-100%). Common uses: Closed for privacy (0%), Partially open for view (30-50%), Open for night view (100%). This overrides the default position after sun sets. Leave blank to keep using default position (no special sunset behavior).
data_description.sunset_offset: Minutes to shift sunset time (± adjustment). Positive value: Apply sunset position X minutes AFTER sunset. Negative value: Apply sunset position X minutes BEFORE sunset. Zero: Exactly at sunset. Use positive value (e.g., 30) if you want blinds to stay in tracking mode a bit past sunset. Use negative value (e.g., -30) to close early for evening privacy.
data_description.sunrise_offset: Minutes to shift sunrise time (± adjustment). Positive value: Start automatic control X minutes AFTER sunrise. Negative value: Start automatic control X minutes BEFORE sunrise. Zero: Exactly at sunrise. Use positive value (e.g., 60) if you want to sleep in past sunrise. Combines with Start Time setting (uses whichever is later).
data_description.climate_mode: Enable advanced climate-aware control based on temperature and weather. When enabled, slat behavior changes by season: WINTER (cold) opens fully on sunny days to gain solar heat; SUMMER (hot) closes fully to prevent overheating; INTERMEDIATE uses normal sun tracking. Requires: Temperature sensor. Optional: Presence, weather, lux sensors. Recommended for energy efficiency.
data_description.tilt_mode: Rotation range of your venetian blind slats. Mode 1 (90°): Standard blinds that rotate 0° (closed/horizontal) to 90° (open/vertical) in one direction. Mode 2 (180°): Premium blinds that can rotate fully through 180° (can tilt upward or downward). Check your blind specs or test manually. Most residential blinds use Mode 1. Mode 2 provides more fine-tuned sun control by allowing the slats to angle in either direction.
data_description.blind_spot: Enable if you have obstacles blocking sun in part of the tracking area (trees, nearby buildings, roof overhang, balcony above). When enabled, you define an azimuth + elevation range where sun is blocked. Slats adjust to default position when sun is in this 'blind spot'. Leave disabled if you have clear view to sun all day.
data_description.min_elevation: Track sun only when elevation is ABOVE this angle (degrees above horizon). Sun elevation: 0°=horizon, 45°=halfway to zenith, 90°=directly overhead. Use this to ignore sun at certain times. Example: Set to 10° to ignore very low morning/evening sun. Leave empty to track sun at all elevations.
data_description.max_elevation: Track sun only when elevation is BELOW this angle (degrees above horizon). Sun elevation: 0°=horizon, 45°=halfway to zenith, 90°=directly overhead. Use this to ignore sun at certain times. Example: Set to 65° to ignore high midday sun. Leave empty to track sun at all elevations.
data_description.interp: Enable custom position mapping (advanced users only). Maps calculated tilt positions to different actual positions using a curve. Use cases: blind doesn't tilt linearly, prefer certain angles (more closed or more open), calibrate for unusual blind behavior. Leave disabled for normal operation. Lists must have equal length.

tilt.description: Configure your tilted/venetian blind. Adjust window orientation, slat dimensions, and tilt behavior for optimal sun blocking and light control.
tilt.title: Tilted cover

data_description.blind_spot_left: Left edge of the blind spot zone (horizontal angle in degrees from your FOV left boundary). Where 0 = at the leftmost FOV edge. Example: If your FOV left is 45° and a tree blocks sun from 10-20° relative to that edge, set this to 10. This marks where the obstruction begins horizontally. Use sun position sensor or observe when sun is blocked to find this value.
data_description.blind_spot_right: Right edge of the blind spot zone (horizontal angle in degrees from your FOV left boundary, must be > left edge). Example: If your FOV left is 45° and a tree blocks sun from 10-20° relative to that edge, set this to 20. This marks where the obstruction ends horizontally. Creates a 'don't track sun here' zone between left and right edges.
data_description.blind_spot_elevation: Maximum sun elevation (degrees above horizon) where blind spot applies. Example: Roof overhang blocks sun only when low (< 30°) so set to 30. Higher elevation sun clears the obstacle, so blind spot doesn't apply. If obstacle blocks all elevations (tall building), set to 90 or leave high. Sun elevation: 0°=horizon, 45°=halfway up, 90°=directly overhead. Measure or estimate based on obstacle height and distance.

blind_spot.title: Blind spot configuration
blind_spot.description: Define areas where obstacles block the sun (trees, buildings, roof overhangs). These angular values are relative degrees within your field of view, where 0 is the leftmost FOV boundary. The cover will ignore sun position when it falls within this blind spot zone.

data_description.interp_start: Physical position value where your cover actually starts to open (simple 2-point calibration). Example: If your cover only starts moving at 10%, set this to 10. Used with interp_end for basic linear mapping. Most covers don't need this - leave at default unless your cover has limited range.
data_description.interp_end: Physical position value where your cover actually reaches fully open (simple 2-point calibration). Example: If your cover is fully open at 90%, set this to 90. Used with interp_start for basic linear mapping. Most covers don't need this - leave at default unless your cover has limited range.
data_description.interp_list: Input positions for custom interpolation mapping (calculated positions from integration). Enter evenly-spaced values like: 0, 25, 50, 75, 100. These are the theoretical positions the integration calculates. Must have 2+ values and same length as Custom interpolation list. Used for advanced non-linear calibration. Leave empty for normal operation.
data_description.interp_list_new: Output positions for custom interpolation mapping (actual positions sent to cover). Enter corresponding real positions like: 0, 20, 40, 65, 100. These are what actually gets sent to your cover entity. Must have same length as List of interpolation. Example use: Make cover more aggressive in closing by mapping 50% calculated to 40% actual. Integration interpolates between your points. Leave empty for normal operation.

interp.title: Range Adjustment
interp.description: Adjust cover position mapping for non-standard behavior. Use simple 2-point adjustment (interp_start/end) for covers with limited range (e.g., only moves between 10-90%). Use advanced list interpolation for non-linear covers or to bias behavior toward more open/closed positions. Most covers don't need this - only enable if your cover doesn't respond correctly to standard 0-100% commands.

data.manual_ignore_intermediate: Ignore intermediate positions during manual override (opening and closing)
data.return_sunset: Always adjust position to sunset default at end time; Useful if end time is before actual sunset

data_description.delta_position: Minimum position change (%) required before adjusting the cover. Prevents tiny adjustments as sun moves slowly. Typical values: 1-2% (very responsive, may adjust frequently), 5% (balanced, recommended for most), 10% (less frequent, larger movements). Example: If cover is at 30% and sun moves slightly, only adjust if new position is 35% or more (with 5% threshold). Reduces motor wear and noise from constant tiny adjustments.
data_description.delta_time: Minimum time (minutes) between cover adjustments. Prevents rapid position changes. Typical values: 2-3 min (very responsive, may be noisy), 5-10 min (balanced, recommended), 15-20 min (slow, gentle adjustments). If sun changes rapidly (clouds, shadows), integration waits this long before adjusting again. Reduces motor wear and provides smoother operation. Minimum is 2 minutes.
data_description.start_time: Don't start automatic control before this time (24-hour format). Use this to sleep in without morning blinds (set to 08:00 or later), match your routine (set to when you wake up), or leave blank to start at sunrise. Example: '07:30' means automatic control begins at 7:30 AM. Manual control still works before this time.
data_description.start_entity: Entity representing starting time state, overriding the fixed start time set above. Useful for automating the start time with an entity (e.g., sensor that provides wake-up time based on calendar or sleep tracking).
data_description.manual_override_duration: How long (minutes) to pause automatic control after manual adjustment. When you manually move the cover, automatic control pauses. Typical values: 10-15 min (short pause, resume tracking soon), 30 min (medium pause, balanced), 60-120 min (long pause, keep manual position longer), 0 (disabled, immediately resume automatic control - not recommended). Gives you control when you want it, resumes automation later.
data_description.manual_override_reset: Reset the manual override timer after each manual adjustment. If enabled, each manual change restarts the override duration. If disabled, the duration only applies to the first manual adjustment (subsequent changes don't extend the pause). Enable this if you want the override period to 'renew' with each manual touch.
data_description.end_time: Stop automatic control after this time (24-hour format). Use this to keep evening privacy (set to 18:00 or 19:00), return to default before bed, or leave blank to continue until sunset. Example: '20:00' means automatic control stops at 8:00 PM. Manual control still works after this time.
data_description.end_entity: Entity representing ending time state, overriding the fixed end time set above. Useful for automating the end time with an entity (e.g., sensor that provides bedtime based on calendar or daily routine).
data_description.manual_threshold: Position difference (%) that counts as 'manual override' (default: 1%). If you manually move cover by this amount, override detection triggers. Typical values: 1-2% (sensitive, detects small adjustments), 5% (less sensitive, recommended), 10% (only large manual changes count). Prevents accidental override detection from small motor drifts or position reporting variations.
data_description.manual_ignore_intermediate: Ignore intermediate positions during manual opening and closing operations. Enable this to prevent override detection from transitional positions while the cover is moving to your target position. Useful if your cover reports many intermediate values during movement.
data_description.return_sunset: Always adjust position to sunset default at end time, even if it's before actual sunset. Enable this to ensure the cover moves to sunset position when the end time is reached, rather than waiting for astronomical sunset. Useful if your end time is before sunset and you want consistent evening positioning.
data_description.open_close_threshold: Position threshold for covers that only support open/close commands (not position control). When the calculated position is greater than or equal to this threshold, the cover opens; when below, it closes. Default: 50% (opens at midpoint or above). Higher values (60-70%) keep cover closed more often, lower values (30-40%) open more often. Only affects covers without position support - covers with position control ignore this setting and use exact calculated positions.
data_description.enable_diagnostics: Enable additional diagnostic sensor entities for debugging and monitoring. When enabled, creates extra entities that show: solar position (azimuth/elevation), last cover action details, control method status, and calculation diagnostics. Default: Disabled (to avoid entity clutter). Enable this if you want detailed visibility into the integration's decision-making process or need to troubleshoot behavior. Diagnostic entities are disabled by default in the UI.

data.inverse_state: Inverse the state (needed for some covers that don't follow HA guidelines)
data.interp: Set custom open/close positions for My Cover, if it doesn't fully operate at 0-100%

data_description.set_azimuth: Direction your window faces (0-359°). North=0°, East=90°, South=180°, West=270°. Example: A south-facing window = 180°. Use a compass app or check sun at noon to determine. This tells the integration where your window points so it can calculate sun angles accurately.
data_description.window_height: Height of your window in meters (from bottom to top of the glass area). Examples: Standard door = 2.0m, Small window = 1.5m, Floor-to-ceiling = 2.5m. Measure from where the cover starts to where it ends when fully extended. Used to calculate optimal cover position to block direct sunlight. Note: 1 meter ≈ 3.3 feet.
data_description.distance_shaded_area: How far you want to ALLOW direct sunlight to reach into the room (in meters). This defines your acceptable 'glare zone' - the area where sunlight can reach the floor. The cover position adjusts to maintain this boundary as the sun moves across the sky. Common configurations: Small glare zone (0.3-0.5m) keeps sunlight very close to the window (use when you want maximum shade); Medium glare zone (0.5-1.0m) allows sun to reach desk or seating area (balanced, most common for living spaces); Large glare zone (2.0-3.0m) allows sunlight deep into the room (good for dark rooms or passive solar heating). KEY CONCEPT: LARGER value = MORE sunlight allowed farther into room = cover stays HIGHER/MORE OPEN; SMALLER value = LESS sunlight into room = cover drops LOWER/MORE CLOSED. Measure from the inside of your window to where you want the sun boundary to be.
data_description.default_percentage: Cover position when sun is not in front of window (0-100%). 0% = Fully closed/lowered (maximum privacy/shade), 50% = Half open (balanced light and privacy), 100% = Fully open/raised (maximum light). This is the 'rest position' used when sun tracking is not active (sun is behind the window, blocked by obstacles, or outside tracking hours).
data_description.max_position: Maximum cover position limit (0-100%). Cover will never go above this value. Use this to: prevent cover from fully opening (set to 80%), keep some shade at all times (set to 60-70%), protect from jamming at top (set to 95%). This creates an upper boundary for all automatic positions.
data_description.fov_left: How wide the sun tracking area is on the LEFT side of the window (in degrees). Standard windows: 45° (90° total coverage with both sides), Wide windows or glass doors: 60-75°, Narrow windows: 30°. Think of this as peripheral vision - how far to the left should we track the sun? Combined with fov_right, this defines the horizontal tracking zone.
data_description.fov_right: How wide the sun tracking area is on the RIGHT side of the window (in degrees). Standard windows: 45° (90° total coverage with both sides), Wide windows or glass doors: 60-75°, Narrow windows: 30°. Think of this as peripheral vision - how far to the right should we track the sun? Combined with fov_left, this defines the horizontal tracking zone.
data_description.group: Select the cover entities to control via this integration instance. You can select multiple covers to control them as a group (all will receive the same position commands). Only select covers that serve this particular window - create separate integration instances for different windows.
data_description.inverse_state: Enable for covers where position logic is reversed. Standard: 0 = closed/lowered, 100 = open/raised. Inverted: 0 = open/raised, 100 = closed/lowered. Check this ONLY if your cover shows opposite behavior, 100% closes instead of opens, or documentation says 'inverted' or 'reversed'. Test your cover manually first to confirm. Most covers don't need this.
data_description.sunset_position: Cover position to set after sunset (0-100%). Common uses: Privacy (0% = fully closed), Open for night air (100%), Partial privacy (30-50%). This overrides the default position after sun sets. Leave blank to keep using default position (no special sunset behavior).
data_description.sunset_offset: Minutes to shift sunset time (± adjustment). Positive value: Apply sunset position X minutes AFTER sunset. Negative value: Apply sunset position X minutes BEFORE sunset. Zero: Exactly at sunset. Use positive value (e.g., 30) if you want covers to stay open a bit past sunset. Use negative value (e.g., -30) to close early while sun is still low.
data_description.sunrise_offset: Minutes to shift sunrise time (± adjustment). Positive value: Start automatic control X minutes AFTER sunrise. Negative value: Start automatic control X minutes BEFORE sunrise. Zero: Exactly at sunrise. Use positive value (e.g., 60) if you want to sleep in past sunrise. Combines with Start Time setting (uses whichever is later).
data_description.climate_mode: Enable advanced climate-aware control based on temperature and weather. When enabled, cover behavior changes by season: WINTER (cold) opens fully on sunny days to gain solar heat; SUMMER (hot) closes fully to prevent overheating; INTERMEDIATE uses normal sun tracking. Requires: Temperature sensor (indoor or outdoor). Optional: Presence sensor, weather integration, lux sensor. Recommended for energy efficiency and comfort.
data_description.blind_spot: Enable if you have obstacles blocking sun in part of the tracking area (trees, nearby buildings, roof overhang, balcony). When enabled, you define an azimuth + elevation range where sun is blocked. Cover ignores sun position when it's in this 'blind spot'. Leave disabled if you have clear view to sun all day.
data_description.min_elevation: Track sun only when elevation is ABOVE this angle (degrees above horizon). Sun elevation: 0°=horizon, 45°=halfway to zenith, 90°=directly overhead. Use this to ignore sun at certain times. Example: Set to 15° to ignore low morning/evening sun. Leave empty to track sun at all elevations.
data_description.max_elevation: Track sun only when elevation is BELOW this angle (degrees above horizon). Sun elevation: 0°=horizon, 45°=halfway to zenith, 90°=directly overhead. Use this to ignore sun at certain times. Example: Set to 60° to ignore high midday sun. Leave empty to track sun at all elevations.
data_description.interp: Enable custom position mapping (advanced users only). Maps calculated positions to different actual positions using a curve. Use cases: cover doesn't move linearly, prefer certain ranges (more closed or more open), calibrate for unusual cover behavior. Leave disabled for normal operation. Lists must have equal length.

vertical.description: Configure your vertical blind or shade. Adjust window orientation, size, and tracking behavior.
vertical.title: Vertical cover

data_description.temp_entity: Temperature sensor for climate mode (indoor or outdoor). Used to determine winter/summer strategies. Indoor sensor recommended (measures room comfort). Outdoor sensor alternative (tracks outside weather). Thermostat: Can use current_temperature attribute. Make sure sensor units match your Home Assistant unit system (°C or °F).
data_description.presence_entity: Optional presence sensor (home/away detection). Supported types: device_tracker, person, zone, binary_sensor. When AWAY: Summer closes fully (save on AC), Winter opens on sunny days (passive solar heating). When HOME: Use normal climate strategies with weather awareness. Leave empty to always assume someone is home. Saves energy when away, maintains comfort when home.
data_description.weather_entity: Optional weather integration for cloud-aware control. When weather = cloudy/rainy: Skips winter solar gain (no sun to capture), Returns to default position (no overheating risk). When weather = sunny/clear: Applies full climate strategies. Leave empty to assume always sunny (simpler). Recommended if you have weather integration - avoids unnecessary closes.
data_description.outside_temp: Optional outdoor temperature sensor for better summer detection. When set, summer mode requires BOTH: Indoor temperature > high threshold AND Outdoor temperature > outside threshold. Prevents closing covers when it's cool outside (open for breeze). Leave empty to use only indoor temperature. Recommended if you have outdoor sensor - improves comfort.
data_description.temp_low: Temperature threshold for WINTER mode (in your system units). When temperature < this value: Cover opens fully on sunny days to gain heat. Recommended values: °C: 18-20°C (65-68°F), °F: 65-68°F. Adjust based on your comfort preference. Lower value = winter mode less often (only when very cold). Higher value = winter mode more often (prioritize solar gain).
data_description.temp_high: Temperature threshold for SUMMER mode (in your system units). When temperature > this value: Cover closes fully to prevent overheating. Recommended values: °C: 23-25°C (73-77°F), °F: 73-77°F. Adjust based on your cooling preference. Lower value = summer mode sooner (aggressive cooling). Higher value = summer mode later (tolerate more heat).
data_description.transparent_blind: Check this if your blind is see-through (sheer/light fabric). Changes summer behavior: Transparent ON closes to 0% in summer (block heat, keep light). Transparent OFF uses calculated position. Transparent blinds reduce heat but allow light through. Leave unchecked for opaque/blackout blinds.
data_description.lux_entity: Optional light intensity sensor for precise sun detection (indoor or outdoor). Measures visible light in lux units. Set threshold value for 'sunny' condition. Typical: 5000-10000 lux for direct sun. When below threshold: Treat as cloudy, skip climate strategies. Leave empty if you don't have this sensor. Advanced feature - most users don't need this.
data_description.lux_threshold: Lux level threshold (when to consider 'sunny'). When sensor reads above this value: Sun is present, apply climate strategies. When below: Treat as cloudy, use default position. Typical values: 5000-10000 lux for direct sunlight, 2000-3000 lux for bright indirect light. Adjust based on sensor placement and sensitivity.
data_description.irradiance_entity: Optional solar radiation sensor for precise sun detection (outdoor). Measures solar power in W/m² units. Set threshold value for 'sunny' condition. Typical: 300-500 W/m² for direct sun. When below threshold: Treat as cloudy, skip climate strategies. Leave empty if you don't have this sensor. Advanced feature - most users don't need this.
data_description.irradiance_threshold: Irradiance level threshold (when to consider 'sunny'). When sensor reads above this value (W/m²): Sun is present, apply climate strategies. When below: Treat as cloudy, use default position. Typical values: 300-500 W/m² for direct sunlight, 100-200 W/m² for cloudy day. Adjust based on your climate and preference.

climate.description: Configure climate-aware control for energy efficiency and comfort. These settings enable the integration to adapt cover behavior based on temperature, weather, and presence.
climate.title: Climate settings

data_description.weather_state: Select weather states that mean 'sun is out' for climate mode. Recommended selection (pre-filled): ☑ sunny (direct sun), ☑ partlycloudy (some sun), ☐ cloudy (no direct sun), ☐ clear (usually night). When current weather matches selection: Apply climate strategies. When no match: Use default position (no sun assumed). Most users should keep the defaults.

data.inverse_state: Inverse the state (needed for some covers that don't follow HA guidelines)
data.interp: Set custom open/close positions for My Cover, if it doesn't fully operate at 0-100%

data_description.set_azimuth: Direction your window/door faces (0-359°). North=0°, East=90°, South=180°, West=270°. Example: A south-facing patio door = 180°. Use a compass app or check sun at noon to determine. This tells the integration where your awning points so it can calculate sun angles accurately.
data_description.window_height: Height of the awning mounting point from the ground or work area level (in meters). This is the vertical distance from the floor/patio to where the awning is attached to the wall. Examples: Standard door height = 2.0-2.5m, Upper window = 3.0m. Used to calculate sun angle and shadow projection.
data_description.length_awning: Maximum extension length of your awning in meters (fully extended). Measure from mounting point to the end of the fabric when fully out. Examples: Standard patio awning = 2.0-3.0m, Small window awning = 1.0-1.5m, Large commercial = 4.0m+. Used to calculate how far the awning needs to extend to block sun.
data_description.angle: Angle of the awning when extended (0-45°). 0° = Horizontal/flat (maximum coverage), 15° = Slight slope (typical for drainage), 30° = Steep slope (strong sun angle), 45° = Very steep (rarely used). Check your awning manufacturer specs. Most awnings are 0-15°. Affects shadow calculation for proper sun blocking.
data_description.distance_shaded_area: How far you want to ALLOW direct sunlight to reach into the covered area (in meters). This defines your acceptable 'glare zone' from the building wall outward. The awning extension adjusts to maintain this boundary as the sun moves. Common: Patio seating (1.5-2.0m), Doorway only (0.5-1.0m), Full patio (2.5-3.5m). KEY CONCEPT: LARGER value = MORE sunlight allowed farther from wall = awning EXTENDS MORE; SMALLER value = LESS sunlight into area = awning RETRACTS MORE. Measure from the wall to where you want the sun boundary to be.
data_description.default_percentage: Awning position when sun is not in front (0-100%). 0% = Fully retracted (protected, stored), 50% = Half extended, 100% = Fully extended (maximum coverage). This is the 'rest position' used when sun tracking is not active. Most users set to 0% to protect awning when not needed.
data_description.max_position: Maximum awning extension limit (0-100%). Awning will never extend beyond this value. Use this to: prevent full extension (set to 80%), keep some retraction for wind safety (set to 70%), protect from over-extension (set to 95%). This creates an upper boundary for all automatic positions.
data_description.fov_left: How wide the sun tracking area is on the LEFT side (in degrees). Standard patios: 45° (90° total coverage with both sides), Wide patios: 60-75°, Narrow doors: 30°. Think of this as peripheral vision - how far to the left should we track the sun? Combined with fov_right, this defines the horizontal tracking zone.
data_description.fov_right: How wide the sun tracking area is on the RIGHT side (in degrees). Standard patios: 45° (90° total coverage with both sides), Wide patios: 60-75°, Narrow doors: 30°. Think of this as peripheral vision - how far to the right should we track the sun? Combined with fov_left, this defines the horizontal tracking zone.
data_description.group: Select the cover entities to control via this integration instance. You can select multiple awnings to control them as a group (all will receive the same position commands). Only select awnings that serve this particular area - create separate integration instances for different locations.
data_description.inverse_state: Enable for awnings where position logic is reversed. Standard: 0 = retracted, 100 = extended. Inverted: 0 = extended, 100 = retracted. Check this ONLY if your awning shows opposite behavior, 100% retracts instead of extends, or documentation says 'inverted' or 'reversed'. Test your awning manually first to confirm. Most awnings don't need this.
data_description.sunset_position: Awning position to set after sunset (0-100%). Common uses: Retract for protection (0% = fully retracted, recommended), Partial extension for evening use (30-50%), Keep extended (100%). This overrides the default position after sun sets. Leave blank to keep using default position (no special sunset behavior).
data_description.sunset_offset: Minutes to shift sunset time (± adjustment). Positive value: Apply sunset position X minutes AFTER sunset. Negative value: Apply sunset position X minutes BEFORE sunset. Zero: Exactly at sunset. Use positive value (e.g., 30) if you want awning to stay extended a bit past sunset. Use negative value (e.g., -30) to retract early for safety.
data_description.sunrise_offset: Minutes to shift sunrise time (± adjustment). Positive value: Start automatic control X minutes AFTER sunrise. Negative value: Start automatic control X minutes BEFORE sunrise. Zero: Exactly at sunrise. Use positive value (e.g., 60) if you want delayed morning extension. Combines with Start Time setting (uses whichever is later).
data_description.climate_mode: Enable advanced climate-aware control based on temperature and weather. When enabled, awning behavior changes by season: WINTER (cold) retracts on sunny days to allow solar heat gain into building; SUMMER (hot) extends fully to prevent overheating; INTERMEDIATE uses normal sun tracking. Requires: Temperature sensor. Optional: Presence, weather, lux sensors. Recommended for energy efficiency.
data_description.blind_spot: Enable if you have obstacles blocking sun in part of the tracking area (trees, nearby buildings, roof overhang, pergola). When enabled, you define an azimuth + elevation range where sun is blocked. Awning ignores sun position when it's in this 'blind spot'. Leave disabled if you have clear view to sun all day.
data_description.min_elevation: Track sun only when elevation is ABOVE this angle (degrees above horizon). Sun elevation: 0°=horizon, 45°=halfway to zenith, 90°=directly overhead. Use this to ignore sun at certain times. Example: Set to 20° to ignore very low sun that clears the awning. Leave empty to track sun at all elevations.
data_description.max_elevation: Track sun only when elevation is BELOW this angle (degrees above horizon). Sun elevation: 0°=horizon, 45°=halfway to zenith, 90°=directly overhead. Use this to ignore sun at certain times. Example: Set to 70° to ignore high sun that doesn't reach under cover. Leave empty to track sun at all elevations.
data_description.interp: Enable custom position mapping (advanced users only). Maps calculated positions to different actual positions using a curve. Use cases: awning doesn't move linearly, prefer certain ranges (more retracted or more extended), calibrate for unusual awning behavior. Leave disabled for normal operation. Lists must have equal length.

horizontal.description: Configure your horizontal awning or canopy. Adjust orientation, dimensions, and extension behavior for optimal sun protection.
horizontal.title: Horizontal cover

data.inverse_state: Inverse the state (needed for some covers that don't follow HA guidelines)
data.interp: Set custom open/close positions for My Cover, if it doesn't fully operate at 0-100%

data_description.set_azimuth: Direction your window faces (0-359°). North=0°, East=90°, South=180°, West=270°. Example: An east-facing window = 90°. Use a compass app or check sun position to determine. This tells the integration where your window points so it can calculate the optimal slat angle to block direct sunlight.
data_description.slat_depth: Width of each slat in meters (measure one slat front to back). Common sizes: Mini blinds (1 inch) = 0.025m, Standard blinds (2 inch) = 0.05m, Wide slats (2.5-3 inch) = 0.065-0.075m. Measure a single slat with a ruler. More precise measurement = better sun blocking calculation. Note: Enter in METERS not centimeters.
data_description.slat_distance: Vertical spacing between slat centers in meters. Measure from the middle of one slat to the middle of the next slat (vertically). Usually slightly more than slat depth to allow overlap when closed. Common: 0.03-0.08m depending on blind type. Used to calculate the tilt angle that blocks all direct sunlight while maximizing view and light. Note: Enter in METERS not centimeters.
data_description.default_percentage: Slat tilt position when sun is not in front of window (0-100%). 0% = Closed horizontal (privacy, darkness), 50% = Partially open (balanced), 100% = Fully open (maximum light). This is the 'rest position' used when sun tracking is not active (sun is behind the window, blocked by obstacles, or outside tracking hours).
data_description.max_position: Maximum slat tilt limit (0-100%). Slats will never open beyond this value. Use this to: keep some privacy at all times (set to 70-80%), never fully open (set to 90%), prevent maximum tilt (set to 95%). This creates an upper boundary for all automatic tilt angles.
data_description.fov_left: How wide the sun tracking area is on the LEFT side of the window (in degrees). Standard windows: 45° (90° total coverage with both sides), Wide windows: 60-75°, Narrow windows: 30°. Think of this as peripheral vision - how far to the left should we track the sun? Combined with fov_right, this defines the horizontal tracking zone.
data_description.fov_right: How wide the sun tracking area is on the RIGHT side of the window (in degrees). Standard windows: 45° (90° total coverage with both sides), Wide windows: 60-75°, Narrow windows: 30°. Think of this as peripheral vision - how far to the right should we track the sun? Combined with fov_left, this defines the horizontal tracking zone.
data_description.group: Select the cover entities to control via this integration instance. You can select multiple venetian blinds to control them as a group (all will receive the same tilt commands). Only select blinds that serve this particular window - create separate integration instances for different windows.
data_description.inverse_state: Enable for blinds where tilt logic is reversed. Standard: 0 = closed/horizontal, 100 = open/vertical. Inverted: 0 = open/vertical, 100 = closed/horizontal. Check this ONLY if your blind shows opposite behavior, 100% closes instead of opens, or documentation says 'inverted' or 'reversed'. Test your blind manually first to confirm. Most blinds don't need this.
data_description.sunset_position: Slat tilt position to set after sunset (0-100%). Common uses: Closed for privacy (0%), Partially open for view (30-50%), Open for night view (100%). This overrides the default position after sun sets. Leave blank to keep using default position (no special sunset behavior).
data_description.sunset_offset: Minutes to shift sunset time (± adjustment). Positive value: Apply sunset position X minutes AFTER sunset. Negative value: Apply sunset position X minutes BEFORE sunset. Zero: Exactly at sunset. Use positive value (e.g., 30) if you want blinds to stay in tracking mode a bit past sunset. Use negative value (e.g., -30) to close early for evening privacy.
data_description.sunrise_offset: Minutes to shift sunrise time (± adjustment). Positive value: Start automatic control X minutes AFTER sunrise. Negative value: Start automatic control X minutes BEFORE sunrise. Zero: Exactly at sunrise. Use positive value (e.g., 60) if you want to sleep in past sunrise. Combines with Start Time setting (uses whichever is later).
data_description.climate_mode: Enable advanced climate-aware control based on temperature and weather. When enabled, slat behavior changes by season: WINTER (cold) opens fully on sunny days to gain solar heat; SUMMER (hot) closes fully to prevent overheating; INTERMEDIATE uses normal sun tracking. Requires: Temperature sensor. Optional: Presence, weather, lux sensors. Recommended for energy efficiency.
data_description.tilt_mode: Rotation range of your venetian blind slats. Mode 1 (90°): Standard blinds that rotate 0° (closed/horizontal) to 90° (open/vertical) in one direction. Mode 2 (180°): Premium blinds that can rotate fully through 180° (can tilt upward or downward). Check your blind specs or test manually. Most residential blinds use Mode 1. Mode 2 provides more fine-tuned sun control by allowing the slats to angle in either direction.
data_description.blind_spot: Enable if you have obstacles blocking sun in part of the tracking area (trees, nearby buildings, roof overhang, balcony above). When enabled, you define an azimuth + elevation range where sun is blocked. Slats adjust to default position when sun is in this 'blind spot'. Leave disabled if you have clear view to sun all day.
data_description.min_elevation: Track sun only when elevation is ABOVE this angle (degrees above horizon). Sun elevation: 0°=horizon, 45°=halfway to zenith, 90°=directly overhead. Use this to ignore sun at certain times. Example: Set to 10° to ignore very low morning/evening sun. Leave empty to track sun at all elevations.
data_description.max_elevation: Track sun only when elevation is BELOW this angle (degrees above horizon). Sun elevation: 0°=horizon, 45°=halfway to zenith, 90°=directly overhead. Use this to ignore sun at certain times. Example: Set to 65° to ignore high midday sun. Leave empty to track sun at all elevations.
data_description.interp: Enable custom position mapping (advanced users only). Maps calculated tilt positions to different actual positions using a curve. Use cases: blind doesn't tilt linearly, prefer certain angles (more closed or more open), calibrate for unusual blind behavior. Leave disabled for normal operation. Lists must have equal length.

tilt.description: Configure your tilted/venetian blind. Adjust window orientation, slat dimensions, and tilt behavior for optimal sun blocking and light control.
tilt.title: Tilted cover

data_description.blind_spot_left: Left edge of the blind spot zone (horizontal angle in degrees from your FOV left boundary). Where 0 = at the leftmost FOV edge. Example: If your FOV left is 45° and a tree blocks sun from 10-20° relative to that edge, set this to 10. This marks where the obstruction begins horizontally. Use sun position sensor or observe when sun is blocked to find this value.
data_description.blind_spot_right: Right edge of the blind spot zone (horizontal angle in degrees from your FOV left boundary, must be > left edge). Example: If your FOV left is 45° and a tree blocks sun from 10-20° relative to that edge, set this to 20. This marks where the obstruction ends horizontally. Creates a 'don't track sun here' zone between left and right edges.
data_description.blind_spot_elevation: Maximum sun elevation (degrees above horizon) where blind spot applies. Example: Roof overhang blocks sun only when low (< 30°) so set to 30. Higher elevation sun clears the obstacle, so blind spot doesn't apply. If obstacle blocks all elevations (tall building), set to 90 or leave high. Sun elevation: 0°=horizon, 45°=halfway up, 90°=directly overhead. Measure or estimate based on obstacle height and distance.

blind_spot.title: Blind spot configuration
blind_spot.description: Define areas where obstacles block the sun (trees, buildings, roof overhangs). These angular values are relative degrees within your field of view, where 0 is the leftmost FOV boundary. The cover will ignore sun position when it falls within this blind spot zone.

data_description.interp_start: Physical position value where your cover actually starts to open (simple 2-point calibration). Example: If your cover only starts moving at 10%, set this to 10. Used with interp_end for basic linear mapping. Most covers don't need this - leave at default unless your cover has limited range.
data_description.interp_end: Physical position value where your cover actually reaches fully open (simple 2-point calibration). Example: If your cover is fully open at 90%, set this to 90. Used with interp_start for basic linear mapping. Most covers don't need this - leave at default unless your cover has limited range.
data_description.interp_list: Input positions for custom interpolation mapping (calculated positions from integration). Enter evenly-spaced values like: 0, 25, 50, 75, 100. These are the theoretical positions the integration calculates. Must have 2+ values and same length as Custom interpolation list. Used for advanced non-linear calibration. Leave empty for normal operation.
data_description.interp_list_new: Output positions for custom interpolation mapping (actual positions sent to cover). Enter corresponding real positions like: 0, 20, 40, 65, 100. These are what actually gets sent to your cover entity. Must have same length as List of interpolation. Example use: Make cover more aggressive in closing by mapping 50% calculated to 40% actual. Integration interpolates between your points. Leave empty for normal operation.

interp.title: Range Adjustment
interp.description: Adjust cover position mapping for non-standard behavior. Use simple 2-point adjustment (interp_start/end) for covers with limited range (e.g., only moves between 10-90%). Use advanced list interpolation for non-linear covers or to bias behavior toward more open/closed positions. Most covers don't need this - only enable if your cover doesn't respond correctly to standard 0-100% commands.
